meta_description: Discover Mexico City, one of the world's great capitals. Explore ancient Aztec ruins, world-class museums, incredible food scenes, and vibrant neighborhoods in this comprehensive CDMX travel guide.

introduction.snippet: Mexico City (CDMX) is one of the world's largest and most dynamic capitals, offering an intoxicating blend of ancient Aztec heritage, Spanish colonial architecture, and cutting-edge contemporary culture. With over 150 museums, UNESCO World Heritage sites, and arguably the best food scene in the Americas, this megacity rewards curious travelers.
introduction.full:
Built on the ruins of the ancient Aztec capital Tenochtitlan, Mexico City is a sprawling metropolis of over 21 million people that defies easy categorization. The historic center (Centro Histórico) showcases magnificent colonial buildings and the excavated Templo Mayor, while trendy neighborhoods like Roma, Condesa, and Coyoacán offer tree-lined streets, Art Deco architecture, and some of the best restaurants in Latin America.

The city's cultural offerings are unmatched: the National Museum of Anthropology houses the world's finest collection of pre-Columbian artifacts, Frida Kahlo's Casa Azul provides intimate insight into the iconic artist's life, and the floating gardens of Xochimilco offer a glimpse of the city's pre-Hispanic past. From world-class galleries to underground speakeasies, from street taco stands to Michelin-starred restaurants, Mexico City delivers experiences that rival any global capital at a fraction of the cost.

attractions.name: National Museum of Anthropology
attractions.description: The world's most important museum of pre-Columbian artifacts, featuring the Aztec Sun Stone and treasures from all major Mesoamerican civilizations.

attractions.name: Zócalo & Historic Center
attractions.description: One of the world's largest public squares, surrounded by the Metropolitan Cathedral, National Palace with Diego Rivera murals, and the excavated Templo Mayor.

attractions.name: Frida Kahlo Museum (Casa Azul)
attractions.description: The iconic blue house where Frida Kahlo was born, lived, and died. Book tickets well in advance as this is Mexico City's most popular museum.

attractions.name: Xochimilco Floating Gardens
attractions.description: Cruise colorful trajinera boats through ancient Aztec canals while mariachis serenade and vendors sell food and drinks from passing boats.

attractions.name: Chapultepec Castle
attractions.description: The only royal castle in the Americas, offering stunning city views and housing the National History Museum.

attractions.name: Teotihuacán Pyramids
attractions.description: Massive ancient city featuring the Pyramid of the Sun and Pyramid of the Moon. About 1 hour from Mexico City center.

faqs.question: Is Mexico City safe for tourists?
faqs.answer: Mexico City's main tourist areas like Roma, Condesa, Polanco, and Centro Histórico are generally safe during the day. Use common sense: take registered taxis or Uber at night, avoid displaying expensive items, and stay aware of your surroundings. The metro is safe during the day but can be crowded.

faqs.question: How many days do you need in Mexico City?
faqs.answer: Plan for at least 4-5 days to experience Mexico City's highlights. This allows time for major museums, the historic center, day trips to Teotihuacán, and exploring different neighborhoods. Food lovers and culture enthusiasts could easily spend 7-10 days.

faqs.question: What is the best neighborhood to stay in Mexico City?
faqs.answer: Roma and Condesa are the most popular neighborhoods for tourists, offering walkable streets, excellent restaurants, and a safe atmosphere. Polanco is upscale and convenient for museums. Centro Histórico puts you at the heart of history but is busier and louder.

faqs.question: Will I experience altitude sickness in Mexico City?
faqs.answer: At 2,240 meters (7,350 feet), some visitors experience mild altitude effects like shortness of breath, headaches, or fatigue. Stay hydrated, avoid alcohol on arrival day, and take it easy for the first 24 hours. Most people adjust within a day or two.

faqs.question: How do I get around Mexico City?
faqs.answer: The metro is extensive and cheap ($0.25 USD) but crowded during rush hours. Uber and DiDi are widely used and affordable. The Metrobús is efficient for major corridors. Walking is pleasant in Roma, Condesa, and Coyoacán. Avoid driving yourself due to traffic.

faqs.question: What is the best time to visit Mexico City?
faqs.answer: March to May offers warm, dry weather before the rainy season. The rainy season (June-October) brings afternoon showers but mornings are usually clear. November-February is cooler and drier. December offers festive decorations, while Day of the Dead (late October/early November) is spectacular.
